headline: Why EA's $55B Saudi deal is 'a head-scratcher'
summary: Electronic Arts (EA) is set to go private in a $55 billion deal. Citi managing director Jason Bazinet joins Asking for a Trend to weigh in on the deal and explain why he thinks the timing of the transaction is odd. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Asking for a Trend.

headline: Stocks to Watch Recap: Electronic Arts, Lockheed Martin, Carnival, Alibaba
summary: ↗️ Electronic Arts (EA): The videogame maker is going private for $52.5 billion in what it billed as the largest-ever private-equity backed buyout. Shares rose 4.5% Monday, while other video-game stocks such as Roblox (RBLX) and Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) also moved higher on the day.

headline: Why EA Is Ready to Quit Wall Street’s Game
summary: The videogame company is going private in a $55 billion deal, as it finally has a potential hit combat game on its hands.

headline: Heard on the Street Recap: The Art of the Deal
summary: Videogame maker Electronic Arts is going private.  A group of investors including Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund agreed to buy the company in a $55 billion deal, which would be the largest leveraged buyout in history.  The company's shares rose 4.5% to $202.05, landing lower than the offer price.

raw.headline: Heard on the Street Recap: The Art of the Deal
raw.summary: Videogame maker Electronic Arts is going private.  A group of investors including Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund agreed to buy the company in a $55 billion deal, which would be the largest leveraged buyout in history.  The company's shares rose 4.5% to $202.05, landing lower than the offer price.

headline: Saudi Plans for Video-Game Hub Grow With $55 Billion EA Deal
summary: In addition to an existing $5 billion equity stake it is rolling over into the new entity, the kingdom’s Public Investment Fund is providing more fresh capital than partners Silver Lake Management and Jared Kushner’s Affinity Partners to buy out the other public investors, according to people familiar with the matter.  The transaction is the latest win for Saudi Arabia’s Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, a video-game fan who is partial to Microsoft Corp.’s He’s focused on gaming as part of a national strategy to provide tens of thousands of new jobs and diversify the kingdom’s economy away from oil.

The transaction is the latest win for Saudi Arabia’s Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, a video-game fan who is partial to Microsoft Corp.’s He’s focused on gaming as part of a national strategy to provide tens of thousands of new jobs and diversify the kingdom’s economy away from oil.

headline: Is Take-Two (TTWO) a Buy as Wall Street Analysts Look Optimistic?
summary: Based on the average brokerage recommendation (ABR), Take-Two (TTWO) should be added to one's portfolio. Wall Street analysts' overly optimistic recommendations cast doubt on the effectiveness of this highly sought-after metric. So, is the stock worth buying?

headline: Take-Two (TTWO) Soars 4.5%: Is Further Upside Left in the Stock?
summary: Take-Two (TTWO) was a big mover last session on higher-than-average trading volume. The latest trend in earnings estimate revisions might not help the stock continue moving higher in the near term.
